rules.description: The list of rules to apply.

id.description: The id of the rule to apply.

anyOf.description: Custom rule following the pattern custom.*Rule$
Use CURRENT-DATE rather than ACCEPT DATE or ACCEPT TIME
Avoid ACCEPT statements containing FROM CONSOLE or FROM SYSIN
Insecure use of ACCEPT
Do not move alphanumeric values to numeric fields.
Avoid use of ALTER for control flow.
Avoid using SECTION in the procedure division
Use binary subscripts
Specify 0 RECORDS for BLOCK CONTAINS clauses in file description entries
Improper restriction of operations within the bounds of a memory buffer
Avoid CALL statements with a literal program name
Avoid CANCEL statements
EXEC SQL: Check the value of SQLCODE after an EXEC SQL statement
Test SQLSTATE after every SQL statement.
Specify COMMAREA length in CICS LINK and CICS XCTL commands.
Use NOHANDLE with CICS commands.
Use an odd number of digits in a COMP-3 or PACKED-DECIMAL data definition
Avoid using the compiler directive
Use the specified prefix with condition names
Avoid COPY SUPPRESS statements
Avoid including the specified copy book
Avoid CORRESPONDING phrases
Explicitly close all explicitly opened cursors.
Do not close cursors inside loops.
Do not declare cursors inside the Procedure Division.
Do not declare cursors inside loops.
Avoid GROUP BY in SQL cursors.
Avoid opening cursors inside loops.
FOR READ ONLY or FOR UPDATE should be specified for DB2 cursors.
Do not deliver code to production with debug features enabled (security-sensitive).
Avoid DISPLAY statements containing UPON CONSOLE
Avoid ENTRY statements
Use an EVALUATE statement rather than a nested IF statement
Use a WHEN OTHER phrase with an EVALUATE statement
Use an EXIT paragraph in each section
Avoid EXIT PROGRAM statements
Explicitly close all open files.
Avoid using MERGE statements.
Follow the specified naming convention for COBOL file names
Do not use OPEN statements inside loops.
Avoid using SORT statements.
Check FILE STATUS after I/O operations when available.
Use level numbers in the sequence 01, 05, 10, 15...
Avoid using GO TO DEPENDING ON.
Avoid GO TO statements, except those that reference an EXIT paragraph
Avoid GO TO statements
Avoid IF without ELSE
Avoid using subscripts to access a table. Use indexes.
Avoid INITIALIZE statements. Use elementary MOVE statements or VALUE clauses.
An inline PERFORM statement cannot exceed the specified line number limit
Avoid using level-88 entries in data descriptions
Avoid using more than one EXIT statement per section
Avoid nesting IF statements deeper than the specified number of levels
Use CONTINUE rather than NEXT SENTENCE inside a scoped range.
Avoid NEXT SENTENCE phrases.
Avoid using DISPLAY statements in production programs.
Avoid OCCURS DEPENDING ON phrases
Use comments to describe all paragraphs
Do not redefine paragraphs.
Avoid PERFORM, except PERFORM section
PERFORM PARAGRAPH should not be used.
Use THRU phrases in PERFORM statements
Avoid THRU phrases in PERFORM statements
Procedure division statements cannot exceed the specified line number limit
Use a program name that matches the source file name
Do not use REDEFINES.
End Clause is Required
Avoid RESERVE clauses in FILE-CONTROL paragraphs
EXEC CICS: Use the RESP option
Avoid calling the specified routine
Use SEARCH ALL rather than SEARCH to search a table
Use comments to describe all sections
EXEC SQL: Avoid SELECT *
EXEC SQL: Use an ORDER BY clause when declaring a cursor
Queries using FETCH FIRST must include an ORDER BY clause.
Improper neutralization of special elements used in an SQL command (SQL Injection)
Do not use CAST(... AS CHAR/VARCHAR) in SQL statements.
Do not use DDL statements in programs.
Do not use LOCK TABLE statements.
Avoid nested SQL SELECT statements.
Do not use UNION in SQL SELECT statements.
Use a WHERE clause in SQL statements
Avoid static calls except for the specified program name
Avoid STOP RUN and STOP literal statements
Move strings only to variables large enough to prevent truncation.
Initialize data items with values of the correct type.
Use of uninitialized variables.
Unprotected Authentication Credentials
Avoid XML PARSE statements
Avoid using data elements of type BIT in arithmetic operations
Avoid using data elements of type CHARACTER in arithmetic operations
Avoid using the PROCESS directive
Use dot qualified references to structure members that are not level 1
Avoid declaring multiple data items by factoring attributes
Avoid FIXED DECIMAL declarations with even precision
Avoid most Go To Statements
Avoid implicit declarations
Use a loop control variable that is FIXED BINARY, FLOAT, ORDINAL, HANDLE, POINTER, or OFFSET.
Use a program name that matches the procedure file name
Declare a single variable in an IF, WHILE, UNTIL, or WHEN clause as BIT(1) NONVARYING
